summary: The project manager opens the meeting by stating the agenda. The industrial designer begins presenting, first describing the insides of a remote control. He lists the options for types of batteries, shapes for the remote case, materials to use, and functions to include such as push buttons, scroll wheels, and LCD screens. He then talks about the type of chip certain features would require. The interface specialist begins presenting, first defining user interface and then showing some examples of remotes. She mentions that many existing remotes do not have a nice appearance, and states her preference for a remote that is small and simple and contains a scrolling wheel. The marketing expert gives her presentation about user requirements and current trends. She shares that fruits and vegetables are popular, meaning curviness and assymetry are in. The group decides to use LCD screens to give the remote style. They discuss what material should be used, talk about how the surface of the case should look, and plan out the general user interface. After they make some decisions about the remote, the project manager closes the meeting by telling them what their tasks will be until the next meeting.
actions: The Industrial Designer will work on look and feel. The Interface Specialist will work on user interface. The Marketing Expert will work on the product evaluation. The two designers will work together on developing a prototype using modeling glay and follow the instructions the group has come up. They will get extra instructions from their personal coach
decisions: The remote control and its buttons will be made of rubber. The case will be flat on top and curved on the bottom. The remote will have push buttons outside, and an LCD and spinning wheel inside. The remote will resemble a vegetable and be in bright vegetable colors. It will have voice recognition, use a simple battery, and contain an advanced chip. It will have standard on/off, channel-changing, numerical, and volume buttons, with a menu on the screen.

   In this meeting we discussed the final disain issues, and evaluated the prototype. Then we calculated the production costs. It turned out that the estimated production costs were over the budject. Since the voice sampler was also ment to be used when locating the remote control, we had to provide an alternative solution. We decided that it would just beep when the locator button that can be attched to the TV (or anywhere else for that matter) is pressed. The whole group was very satisfied with the design of the prototype. We expect the product to be great success.

Teletext outdated!

0:
Presented by: Maarika Traat
User Interface Designer
1:
User interface: The aspects of a computer system or program which can be seen (or heard or otherwise perceived) by the human user, and the commands and mechanisms the user uses to control its operation and input data.
E.g. Shape, size, buttons, voice-recognition,
Colour, etc.
2:
Research the interfaces of related products, mainly on the internet.
Analyse their user friendliness
Assess their appearance
Decide which features to incorporate in the design of our product.
3:
In the case of most of the remote controls the interface consists of a clutter of button functions, colors, and forms. This inconsistent use of interface is confusing and doesn't improve the use of the product.
 New user interface component – voice recognition (record up to 80 voice samples)
A spinning wheel with LC display 
A scroll button with integrated push button (such as in modern computer mouse) at the side of the remote 
Latest developments of the manufacturing division of our company – programmable speech speaker unit – add on to voice recognition
4: Personal Preferences

Keep it small
Keep it simple
Include voice recognition
Standard major buttons
Other function via menu on screen

0: Presented by: Maarika Traat,  User Interface Designer
1:
Search the web for inspiration from similar devices. 
Think about user needs and desires
Think about the main function of the remote control
2:
The function of a remote control is to send messages to the television set. 
"switch on
"switch off“
"switch to next channel“
"switch to channel 9“
"turn volume up"
3:
The present standard seems to be that besides TV functions the remotes also have functions to operate a VSR.
They do not seem to be able to handle the requirements of DVD players.
4: Personal Preferences

Keep it small
Easy to use
The “must have” buttons
On/off
Channel numbers, next/previous channel
Volume
Menu for more complicated functions (e.g. brightness)
Do we want to incorporate Video and DVD related functions?  - (No: last minute update on the project spec.)

1:
Preparing the evaluation of the new design

This should be done using a 7 point scale where 1 is TRUE and 7 is FALSE, as regarding the design meeting a certain criteria.
This is based on the collection of criteria on the user requirements and trends found in the marketing reports and the marketing strategy of the Real Reaction © electronics company.
2:
The remote control should:
be attractive to look at
match the operating behaviour of the user
be locatable
be intuitive
have an ergonomic design to reduce risk of RSI
have voice control
be technologically innovative
put fashion into electronics

1:
Usability lab observed remote control use amongst 100 subjects, who then filled in a questionnaire. They investigated:
- What the users think about the look and feel of current remote controls.
The biggest frustrations of using remote controls
Speech recognition and LCD screens in remote controls.
2:
Users dislike the look and feel of current remote controls.
75% of users find most remote controls ugly 
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy 
Current remote controls do not match well the operating behavior of the user 
75% of users said they zap a lot 
50% of users say they only use 10% of the buttons
3:
The graph shows that the most predominant uses of the remote is for
Chanel Selection
Teletext (including flipping pages)
Volume Control
4: Frustrations

Remote controls are often lost somewhere in the room (50%) 
It takes too much time to learn how to use a new remote control (34%) 
Remote controls are bad for RSI (26%)
6:
Sleek
Stylish
Sophisticated
Functional
Minimalist
Long battery life
Solar power
Locator (clap and then it beeps?)

doc.content:
Final report



Team: 	Jen (Project Manager)

Cat (Marketing Expert)

Gaurav (Industrial Design)

Maarika (User Interface Design)



Product: Television remote control



Technical specifications:

	- internal simple battery

	- rubber case, curved on 1 side, hinged to flip open

	- push buttons for power, and channels on front

	- push buttons for volume on side

	- LCD display with spinning wheel on inside for all other functions

	- advanced chip

	- voice recognition

	- separate locator to be attached to TV which will make remote ‘beep’

	 

	- yellow banana-look with black buttons and grey company logo



Product evaluation

Attractive			7

Match operating behaviour	6

Be locatable			7

Be intuitive			5

Ergonomic to reduce RSI	6

Voice control			7

Technologically innovative	6

Put fashion in electronics	7



Average			6.4



Product description:

An innovative, new-look TV remote control aimed at 15-35’s, the Real Reaction © product is in advance of trends in its spongy, vegetable-like look-and-feel. Combining a simple push button interface with the most popular remote commands and a flip-open LCD display and spinning wheel for advanced functionality, the product will revolutionise TV in this country and globally. Voice-recognition and built-in speaker increase ease-of-use and appeal to the designated target group, and the rubber casing and ergonomic design prevent damage and reduce the risk of RSI.

 

Design process:

The product was designed by a team of experts, each with his or her own speciality. The design process worked smoothly, interspersing individual work with regular meetings to consolidate knowledge gained and make key design decisions. Decision making was by consensus and all team members contributed to the process. The team worked well together and all minor differences were resolved through discussion. Technological resources (PowerPoint, laptops, whiteboards, email) were used appropriately and facilitated the smooth progression of the process.

Minutes of initial meeting



Time: 11am, 28 Jan. 05

Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID)



 

 [ABSTRACT]   



 The meeting functioned as an introduction to the team and the project. After an initial brief of the project, team members introduced themselves and their roles (see present above). The project finances were outlined, and then initial ideas for the product were briefly discussed.



	 [DECISIONS]   

	

	 No decisions were made as this was an introductory meeting.

	The initial ideas which were suggested by the marketing expert were agreed by the group - that we should go for a sleek look which fits with other products marketed by this company. This may involve having few or no buttons on the remote as many of these are rarely used anyway. 

	The user interface designer cautioned against  using a design which is too different from what consumers are used to as this will reduce the usability of the device.

	

	[ACTIONS]  

	 

	Actions to be taken:

	ID: the working design

	UID: the technical functions design

	ME: the user requirements specification  

	PM: liaise with management, prepare minutes and next meeting

Minutes of second meeting



Time: 12:05pm, 28 Jan. 05

Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID)



[ABSTRACT]   



 This meeting brought together the initial individual work of the two designers and marketing expert. Each presented their ideas on working design, technical functions design and functional design respectively - presentations can be found in the project documents folder. Discussion followed, the result of which was a decision on target group and functionality



	 [DECISIONS]  


	Target group - 15-35 – this implies incorporating voice recognition

	Design - small, sleek, sexy, but must follow some conventions for ease of use

	Functionality - volume, channel, power, menu, no teletext

	Locator – perhaps to attach to TV

	TV only – unless we can make a case to management that other things (eg video, DVD) should be supported as well, as most other models do this

	Voice recognition (we need to investigate implications of this before committing fully) – would be great if it could recognise channels, not just numbers

	

	 [PROBLEMS/ISSUES] 


	Suggestions from management were incorporated with little trouble.

	Any extra functionality will make the chip bigger. This needs to be kept in mind during design. Likewise the cost implications of greater functionality.

	The possibility of an LCD screen was not explored.

	The design should be ergonomic to prevent RSI.

	

	[ACTIONS]  

	 

	ID: components concept

	UID: user interface concept

	ME: trend watching

	PM: liaise with management, keep team updated

	 

	All to consider implications/feasibility of incorporating voice recognition and keep our target group in mind when designing.

Minutes of second meeting



Time: 14:15pm, 28 Jan. 05

Present: Jen (PM), Cat (ME), Gaurav (ID), Maarika (UID)



[ABSTRACT]   



This meeting focussed on the concepts of the remote control, including components, properties, materials, user interface and response to trends. Each team member presented their findings and gave reasons for their preferred design choices. The meeting resulted in consensus on design specifications.



	[DECISIONS]   


	 Technical specifications:

	- internal simple battery

	- rubber case, curved on 1 side, hinged to flip open

	- push buttons for power, volume and channels on outside

	- LCD display with spinning wheel on inside

	- voice recognition

	- advanced chip

	- sender and speaker if costs permit

	 

	- 'fruit and vegetable' colours - orange, green, maybe red, yellow, purple

	- company colours can be incorporated in button design

	

	[ACTIONS]  

	 

	ID - look and feel design - model

	UID - user interface design - model

	ME - product evaluation

	PM – final report
